displayed_text: Family Member: It was very interesting. And we was laughing because- Doctor: What cities did you go to in South Africa? Did you visit any cities or-? Patient: We was all over the place. Family Member: Um hum. We was in Cape Town, Johannesburg, these little towns. Patient: Swaziland. Family Member: Swaziland. Patient: Zululand. Hazyview. Family Member: There, we had to cross the border. And so we had to go and show your passport, get stamped, or whatever, and go back across the border. Doctor: To Swaziland? Is that a-? Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s like one of those little countries that’s inside of some? Patient: Um hum. Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now one question that patients always ask me is “Is it possible you know for the uh testosterone to make the cancer worse?” In other words, could it accelerate or stimulate or speed up the cancer? Patient: Uh huh. My thoughts also. Doctor: And you know that was one of the very first things we thought of when we were designing these trials for uh patients and the first trial of this approach started in around twenty thirteen. And so we’ve been doing this for three or four years now. And in our initial studies, fortunately we did not see any cases where prostate cancer appeared to accelerate. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So we basically saw one of three patterns. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the first is, which is the most promising, is that the cancer goes into remission. That’s about one-third of patients. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then in about one-third of patients, the cancer neither grows nor shrinks. So it basically stabilizes. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And that stabilization typically lasts anywhere from six to twelve months. So it’s not permanent. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: You know, it was a little, uh I was really hoping that this would start the numbers to decrease, that was what I was anticipating at the very beginning, but I knew there was a possibility that they would be going up. So just a little disappointed – Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - that they have been going up. I think that the thing that kept me most uh calm with it was that they weren’t increasing you know as fast as they were before I went You know a person coming into the study with um, I think it was around four when I really started noticing the stuff going and now we’re somewhere around twenty-eight, twenty-nine. Family Member: Twenty-eight. Patient: Yeah. So you know. But that was (chuckles) Doctor: But it, it has slowed down a little bit, you know we design studies you know, we want things to slow down but really what we want to see is you know, huge and immediate increases. So we always sort of go for the home run and then sometimes you know we might get a single and double, Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but you really want to go for the home run. So we do not have a home run. We all know that by now. We have patients on this study where um they get the same drug you’ve got or the same dose – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - and their PSA drops by ninety-eight percent in the first two months. We’ve seen that. You’re not one of those guys. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We also have other people where the PSA continues to increase at the same pace or in some people it even speeds up. So you’re not in that category either. Then we have some people where the PSA you know slows down, they stay on the drug for anywhere between four to six months. It’s probably doing something, but it’s not know the desired effect or the absolute you know, perfect effect that we expected, so it’s sort of a middle ground, and yet it’s hard to justify you know to keep going if all you’re seeing is like a lukewarm type of response. Patient: Right, right, right.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Once you’ve had a CRYO, we automatically keep the CAT scans that have had CRYO for the person who did the CRYO to read. So he’s the only one who would read them (papers shuffling) Patient: To see what happens, what’s going on. Doctor: Yeah, because the report - Healthcare Professional: It could switch; the report doesn’t say it helped. It didn’t say it was Doctor: No, I agree. Family Member: And to report that you got back. Doctor: Yeah, they didn’t have that perspective. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They were just busy measuring just for the sake of studying and seeing what Family Member: This way it keeps Doctor: Exactly, yeah. They weren’t looking at what’s closer; that was not in there, factored into their thinking about what treatment impact it would have. Patient: Well, you know it’s kind uh; it’s hard to understand.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Hm Hmm. Doctor: you can sorta plan it out. So, the week that’s the scariest is if you get your chemo and Christmas and all those people are there seven to ten days after, that’s dangerous. Healthcare Professional: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Okay, but, if it’s the twenty, you know the eighteenth day of the cycle… Patient: So, apply the no-fly rule. Doctor: ‘Cuz again if Healthcare Professional: Yes. Doctor: his counts are already up and ready for the next cycle, that’s the safest. Family Member: Oh, got it. Got it. Yep, I see that. I see that. Math makes sense. Yep. Family Member: Now, I just have to remember it. (pause) Patient: We’ll see, we’ll just try to make it happen. We’ll just schedule it out. Family Member: Mmm. I think we might go with the artificial, artificial tree. Aren’t we glad we

Family Member: Uh, huh. Doctor: are possible side effects of these medications. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But those are things that you cannot just sit at home and wait until your next appointment and you elicit- Family Member: I don’t know who to call. I’m a registered nurse. Doctor: I know. Family Member: I’m going to keep my eye on- Family Member: Yes. Yes. Doctor: Because you have the training already. Family Member: You’re going to have to listen to me, J___, okay? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But she said is so vitally important -

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um, we’ll have to see um what the PSA test looks like today. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But in the last few months it has been going up. Patient: I know it’s high today. Doctor: How do you know that? Patient: I- because I been taking that medicine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And then then I be feelin’- I be for the last Doctor: Okay. Patient: Sometime that would go away. Sometime it stay with me the whole day so. I I wadn’t worryin’ that I’m sayin’ I’m wonderin’ i-i-s it possible its cancer or medicine so. Doctor: In addition to the heartburn, are there any other new symptoms. Are you having any pain in the bones or elsewhere?

Patient: Oh yeah. That’s the best case scenario. Doctor: …then the cancer is giving us a break and you can deal with your… Patient: Right other stuff. Doctor: …neck issue and spine and penis issue too. Laughs]] Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now that we’re on tape let’s document this. It’s real. You have to face it. Family Member: We’re being nice to them and saying here, look at this. & DOC Laughing]] Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay so first of all let me go ask Dr. L____ if he can see you today. Patient: Okay, oh yeah? That would be nice. Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Let me go check with him. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: I wanted, I want your input, uh but we couldn’t just give him that - because he is all at that level of three injections of testosterone, he’s a perfect candidate just for that immune thing just to see? (Beeping) Doctor: Well, the immune thing is normally I, I don’t. We’re not allowed to give anything unless it’s in a disease where it’s been approved- Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: because the cost is so very high, the hospital won’t let us do anything. So normally what we have to do is go through the insurance company, tell them what we wanted to do, they deny it, you write letters. So it’s not something that I can just do it tomorrow. Family Member: So you can’t ask-? Doctor: Now you, you know, who have, you’re a person of means, that maybe you could just pay for it, but I haven’t really, I don’t know what the avenue is to do that. (Laughs) Family Member: Well- Patient: Give, give that some thought, too. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Like maybe it’s, if you think it is worthwhile doing since I’m already trying with the testosterone to do it, uh. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You can follow a number of avenues. Doctor: I could ask the pharmacist if there’s a way that, you know, if the patient could actually just pay for it themselves and just get it.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It could be a cancer spot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or it could be that you bled into your adrenal gland, and so, uh, hemorrhaged into the adrenal gland. Was that your aspirin? You know, I don’t know why people do that. But you can spontaneously do that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. Is it a side effect of the drug? I don’t know. But is it a cancer spot? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, let’s go to the data. You are on therapy, really tolerating it okay? Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And I would say, no worse for the wear? Patient: Nope. Doctor: Um, we have scans that are sort of trending worse but nothing definitively worse --- by new other than the adrenal thing, and that is hedging. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So I think that is something to track down obviously, but um we’ll have to see how it goes. I’m just hoping you know we definitely have the Lynparza sort of as a fall back. Um again- Patient: So I’d be two steps away from chemo. Doctor: But getting that as well not quite and who knows how many more steps we’ll find as we go along, you know. Like I said this BET inhibitor wasn’t there what six months ago if you had needed this option and it wasn’t there for you. So it’s changed very rapidly. Patient: Everything is brand new. Doctor: Yeah but obviously we should jump on that if we can. Patient: And will they give me the uh BET thing as part of the clinical trial? Doctor: Yeah, yeah that is part of it. Patient: So I’m in a new clinical trial basically. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And they’ll give me that as part of the clinical trial Doctor: Absolutely Patient: so no out-of-pocket for us?

Family Member: There’s a halo around you that you don’t see, but we do. That’s why we’re here. Doctor: Well thank you. Family Member: Seriously. Family Member: Because you care, that she listens. Doctor: But and I have also have some donor money Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If you know, for medical expenses Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: if it’s getting to be too much let me know, bring it in, and then we’ll consider that. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Alright Family Member: We appreciate you. Thank you for your input.

Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted? Doctor: He could but just it's challenging to do that because you're kind of have the baby right here. You’re hugging her. Patient: Uh I don’t think Family Member 1: She’s two years old. He lifts her up the crib. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: But we're worried can she get cancer from him? Like from being around him? Doctor: No, she can't get sick from him. Family Member 1: Write that down. Doctor: It's more like she’s going to be tough for you. And the mask can only do so much. Family Member 1: In case she picks up a virus from her. Family Member 2: She goes to classes around other kids. Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member 2: Can the mask cover it?

Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: - depending on. And then um in point six percent of people you could get a seizure. I point that out out of all the list because that’s to me the most scary - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - if it were me. But you know point six is less – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - than one as in we give this stuff all the time and people, knock on wood - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - have not had it as an issue. Family Member: Everybody has their issues. Doctor: It is. So every time you read that consent form it’s like you opened up a bottle of Motrin, took out the little package insert, (HCP laughing) Family Member: You know even one person Doctor: Um hum. FAM - who’s on the study said oh I had seizures – Healthcare Professional: You have to write it down.

Patient: But just take the rest of those? Doctor: And then I’ll have you come back next week. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. (pause doctor whispering) Patient: So finish these off and don’t refill. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I’m going to add on a testosterone level today so that will give me information by tomorrow. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. (pause8sec) Patient: Yes. Healthcare Professional: Yes that’s today’s. (pause6sec) Doctor: The good news is you’re not feeling any different. Right?
